name: Bree
headline: Chime for Canada, starting with cash advances
description: Bree is building a challenger bank for the 11 million Canadians living paycheck to paycheck, starting with interest-free cash advances. We make money through tips and an optional, same-day express fee. By solving our customers' most urgent problem—illiquidity between paychecks —our cash advance business is a cheap, but profitable and repeatable hook that builds distribution for a broader challenger bank. This represents a $9 billion revenue opportunity in Canada.

founders.name: Alexander Li, Founder
founders.description: Born in China, raised in Canada and currently based out of Vancouver. Studied CS + Business in college and did 2 years of investment banking at JP Morgan in San Francisco prior to working on start-ups.

founders.name: Adam Kang, Founder
founders.description: Founder at Bree. Previously worked in investment banking at J.P. Morgan and as a software engineer at Darkstore.

generated_description:
Bree is a Vancouver-based fintech startup that aims to transform financial wellbeing for the 11 million Canadians living paycheck to paycheck. Founded in 2021 as part of Y Combinator's S21 cohort, Bree is setting out to be a challenger bank with a keen focus on providing interest-free cash advances, addressing the urgent liquidity issues that many Canadians face.

Imagine needing to cover a bill before your next paycheck hits—Bree allows users to access cash advances up to $500 without any interest or hidden fees. The company makes its money through optional tips and a same-day express fee. This innovative approach not just meets an immediate need but lays the groundwork for a wider banking solution in the future. With an estimated $9 billion revenue potential in Canada for cash advances alone, Bree's business model is both profitable and scalable.

Bree’s mission, “Chime for Canada,” is all about empowering users towards financial wellness. They offer tools like budgeting help and a weekly newsletter that encourages better financial habits. In stark contrast to payday lenders, which often ensnare borrowers in a cycle of debt, Bree encourages a community-supported repayment model. Customers can tip Bree for its services, akin to leaving a gratuity for good service at a restaurant, fostering a sense of community and self-advocacy among users.

The startup operates with a tight-knit team of two and continues expanding its reach, currently boasting a loyal customer base of over 350,000. While Dalton Caldwell serves as a Group Partner, Bree remains laser-focused on supporting its users without the burden of traditional fees, offering them a chance to pay back at their own pace.

You can explore more about what Bree is up to on their [website](https://www.trybree.com/). If you're in Canada and often find yourself short on cash, Bree’s interest-free advances might just be the financial lifebuoy you've been looking for.
